**What to Do in Case of Overdose**

Call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911.

**Important Information**

*   Do not let anyone else take your medication.
*   Ask your pharmacist any questions you have about refilling your prescription.
*   Keep a supply of didanosine on hand. Do not wait until you run out of medication to refill your prescription.
*   Keep a written list of all the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital.

**Brand Names**

*   Videx EC
*   Videx

**Other Names**

*   ddI
*   dideoxyinosine

title: Dieffenbachia poisoning: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Dieffenbachia Poisoning**

Dieffenbachia is a type of house plant with large, colorful leaves. Poisoning can occur if you eat or are exposed to the leaves, stalk, or root of this plant.

**This Article is for Information Only**

DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States.

**Poisonous Ingredients**

*   Oxalic acid
*   Asparagine, an amino acid found in this plant

**Symptoms**

*   Blisters in the mouth
*   Burning in mouth and throat
*   Diarrhea
*   Hoarse voice
*   Increased saliva production
*   Nausea and vomiting
*   Pain on swallowing
*   Redness, swelling, pain, and burning of the eyes, and possible corneal damage
*   Swelling of mouth and tongue

**Home Care**

Wipe out the mouth with a cold, wet cloth. Rinse the person's eyes and skin well if they touched the plant.

Give the person milk, unless instructed otherwise by poison control or a health care provider. DO NOT give milk if the person is having symptoms (such as vomiting, convulsions, or a decreased level of alertness) that make it hard to swallow.

Call poison control for more guidance.

**Before Calling Emergency**

Get the following information:

*   Person's age, weight, and condition
*   Parts of the plant that were eaten, if known
*   Time swallowed
*   Amount swallowed

**Poison Control**

Your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. This national hotline will let you talk to experts in poisoning. They will give you further instructions.

This is a free and confidential service. All local poison control centers in the United States use this national number. You should call if you have any questions about poisoning or poison prevention. It does NOT need to be an emergency. You can call for any reason, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

**What to Expect at the Emergency Room**

Take the plant with you to the hospital, if possible.

The provider will monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Symptoms will be treated as needed. The person may receive fluids through a vein (IV) and breathing support. Damage to the cornea will require additional treatment, possibly from an eye specialist.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

If contact with the person's mouth is not severe, symptoms usually resolve within a few days. For people who do have severe contact with the plant, a longer recovery time may be necessary.

In rare cases, swelling is severe enough to block the airways.

DO NOT touch or eat any plant with which you are not familiar. Wash your hands after working in the garden or walking in the woods.

**Alternative Names**

*   Dumbcane poisoning
*   Leopard lily poisoning
*   Tuft root poisoning

**References**

*   Graeme KA. Toxic plant ingestions. In: Auerbach PS, Cushing TA, Harris NS, eds. Auerbach's Wilderness Medicine. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 65.
*   Lim CS, Aks SE. Plants, herbal medications, and mushrooms. In: Walls RM, , ed. Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts and Clinical Practice. 10th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 153.

**Review Date**

11/2/2023

**Updated by**

Jesse Borke, MD, CPE, FAAEM, FACEP, Attending Physician at Kaiser Permanente, Orange County, CA. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

**Learn how to cite this page**

Dieffenbachia poisoning is a serious condition that requires immediate attention. If you suspect someone has ingested or come into contact with dieffenbachia, call your local emergency number or poison control center right away.

---

**Dieffenbachia Poisoning**

This article is for information only. DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States.

**Poisonous Ingredients**

*   Oxalic acid
*   Asparagine, an amino acid found in this plant

**Symptoms**

*   Blisters in the mouth
*   Burning in mouth and throat
*   Diarrhea
*   Hoarse voice
*   Increased saliva production
*   Nausea and vomiting
*   Pain on swallowing
*   Redness, swelling, pain, and burning of the eyes, and possible corneal damage
*   Swelling of mouth and tongue

    Blistering and swelling in the mouth may be severe enough to prevent normal speaking and swallowing.

**Home Care**

*   Wipe out the mouth with a cold, wet cloth. Rinse the person's eyes and skin well if they touched the plant.
*   Give the person milk, unless instructed otherwise by poison control or a health care provider. DO NOT give milk if the person is having symptoms (such as vomiting, convulsions, or a decreased level of alertness) that make it hard to swallow.
*   Call poison control for more guidance.

**Before Calling Emergency**

*   Get the following information:
    *   Person's age, weight, and condition
    *   Parts of the plant that were eaten, if known
    *   Time swallowed
    *   Amount swallowed

**Poison Control**

Your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. This national hotline will let you talk to experts in poisoning. They will give you further instructions.

This is a free and confidential service. All local poison control centers in the United States use this national number. You should call if you have any questions about poisoning or poison prevention. It does NOT need to be an emergency. You can call for any reason, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

**What to Expect at the Emergency Room**

*   Take the plant with you to the hospital, if possible.
*   The provider will monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Symptoms will be treated as needed. The person may receive fluids through a vein (IV) and breathing support. Damage to the cornea will require additional treatment, possibly from an eye specialist.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

*   If contact with the person's mouth is not severe, symptoms usually resolve within a few days. For people who do have severe contact with the plant, a longer recovery time may be necessary.
*   In rare cases, swelling is severe enough to block the airways.
*   DO NOT touch or eat any plant with which you are not familiar. Wash your hands after working in the garden or walking in the woods.

---

**Dieffenbachia Poisoning**

\n\n**Symptoms**

*   Swelling of the mouth, tongue, and lips that can lead to difficulty breathing if severe enough to block the airways.

**Prevention**

*   DO NOT touch or eat any plant with which you are not familiar.
*   Wash your hands after working in the garden or walking in the woods.

\n\n**Alternative Names**

*   Dumbcane poisoning
*   Leopard lily poisoning
*   Tuft root poisoning

\n\n**References**

*   Graeme KA. Toxic plant ingestions. In: Auerbach PS, Cushing TA, Harris NS, eds. Auerbach's Wilderness Medicine. 7th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2017:chap 65.
*   Lim CS, Aks SE. Plants, herbal medications, and mushrooms. In: Walls RM, , ed. Rosen's Emergency Medicine: Concepts and Clinical Practice. 10th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2023:chap 153.

\n\n**Review Date**

title: Diesel oil: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Diesel Oil Poisoning**

Diesel oil is a heavy oil used in diesel engines. Diesel oil poisoning occurs when someone swallows diesel oil.

**This Article Is For Information Only**

DO NOT use it to treat or manage an actual poison exposure. If you or someone you are with has an exposure, call your local emergency number (such as 911), or your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States.

**Poisonous Ingredient**

Various hydrocarbons

**Where Found**

Diesel oil

**Symptoms**

Diesel oil poisoning can cause symptoms in many parts of the body.

* **EYES, EARS, NOSE, AND THROAT**
	+ Loss of vision
	+ Severe pain in the throat
	+ Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
* **GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM**
	+ Blood in the stool
	+ Burns of the throat (esophagus)
	+ Severe abdominal pain
	+ Vomiting
	+ Vomiting blood
* **HEART AND BLOOD VESSELS**
	+ Collapse
	+ Low blood pressure that develops rapidly (shock)
* **LUNGS AND AIRWAYS**
	+ Breathing difficulty
	+ Empyema (infected fluid surrounding the lungs)
	+ Hemorrhagic pulmonary edema (bloody fluid in the lungs)
	+ Lung irritation and cough
	+ Respiratory distress or failure
	+ Pneumothorax (lung collapse, partial or complete)
	+ Pleural effusion (fluid surrounding the lungs, reducing their ability to expand)
	+ Secondary bacterial or viral infection
	+ Throat swelling (may also cause breathing difficulty)
* **NERVOUS SYSTEM**
	+ Agitation
	+ Blurred vision
	+ Brain damage from low oxygen levels (may lead to memory issues and decreased ability to think clearly)
	+ Coma (decreased level of consciousness and lack of responsiveness)
	+ Confusion
	+ Decreased coordination
	+ Dizziness
	+ Headache
	+ Seizures
	+ Somnolence (sleepiness and decreased responsiveness)
	+ Weakness
* **SKIN**
	+ Burns
	+ Irritation

**Home Care**

Seek medical help right away. Do not make a person throw up unless told to do so by poison control or a health care professional.

If the chemical was swallowed, immediately give the person water or milk, unless instructed otherwise by a health care provider. Do not give water or milk if the person is having symptoms (such as vomiting, convulsions, or a decreased level of alertness) that make it hard to swallow.

If the chemical is on the skin or in the eyes, flush with lots of water for at least 15 minutes.

**Before Calling Emergency**

Get the following information:

* The person's age, weight, and condition
* Name of the product (ingredients and strengths, if known)
* Time it was swallowed
* Amount swallowed

**Poison Control**

Your local poison control center can be reached directly by calling the national toll-free Poison Help hotline (1-800-222-1222) from anywhere in the United States. This national hotline will let you talk to experts in poisoning. They will give you further instructions.

This is a free and confidential service. All local poison control centers in the United States use this national number. You should call if you have any questions about poisoning or poison prevention. It does NOT need to be an emergency. You can call for any reason, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

**What to Expect at the Emergency Room**

The provider will measure and monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Symptoms will be treated as appropriate. The person may receive:

* Blood and urine tests
* Breathing support, including oxygen given through a tube through the mouth into the lungs, and breathing machine (ventilator)
* Bronchoscopy -- camera down the throat to see burns in the airways and lungs
* Chest x-ray
* ECG (heart tracing)
* Endoscopy -- camera down the throat to see burns in the esophagus (swallowing tube) and the stomach
* Fluids through the vein (by IV)
* Medicine to treat symptoms
* Surgical removal of burned skin (skin debridement)
* Tube through the mouth into the stomach to aspirate (suck out) the stomach, but only in cases of massive ingestion if the victim is seen within an hour of swallowing the poison and if there is no injury to the esophagus
* Washing of the skin (irrigation), perhaps every few hours for several days

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

How well the person does depends on the amount of poison swallowed and how quickly treatment is received. The faster the person gets medical help, the better the chance for recovery.

Swallowing diesel fuel can damage the linings of the:

* Esophagus
* Intestines
* Mouth
* Stomach
* Throat

Serious and permanent damage can occur if the diesel gets into the lungs.

Delayed injury may occur, including a hole forming in the throat, esophagus, stomach or lungs. This can lead to severe bleeding and infection, and may be fatal. Surgery may be needed to treat these complications.

The harsh taste of diesel fuel makes it unlikely that a large amount will be swallowed. However, cases of poisoning have occurred in people trying to suck (siphon) gas from an automobile tank using their mouth and a garden hose (or similar tube). This practice is very dangerous and is not advised.

---

**Symptoms**

Diesel oil poisoning can cause symptoms in many parts of the body.

* **EYES, EARS, NOSE, AND THROAT**
	+ Loss of vision
	+ Severe pain in the throat
	+ Severe pain or burning in the nose, eyes, ears, lips, or tongue
* **GASTROINTESTINAL SYSTEM**
	+ Blood in the stool
	+ Burns of the throat (esophagus)
	+ Severe abdominal pain
	+ Vomiting
	+ Vomiting blood
* **HEART AND BLOOD VESSELS**
	+ Collapse
	+ Low blood pressure that develops rapidly (shock)
* **LUNGS AND AIRWAYS**
	+ Breathing difficulty
	+ Empyema (infected fluid surrounding the lungs)
	+ Hemorrhagic pulmonary edema (bloody fluid in the lungs)
	+ Lung irritation and cough
	+ Respiratory distress or failure
	+ Pneumothorax (lung collapse, partial or complete)
	+ Pleural effusion (fluid surrounding the lungs, reducing their ability to expand)
	+ Secondary bacterial or viral infection
	+ Throat swelling (may also cause breathing difficulty)
* **NERVOUS SYSTEM**

The provider will measure and monitor the person's vital signs, including temperature, pulse, breathing rate, and blood pressure. Symptoms will be treated as appropriate. The person may receive:

* Blood and urine tests
* Breathing support, including oxygen given through a tube through the mouth into the lungs,and breathing machine (ventilator)
* Bronchoscopy -- camera down the throat to see burns in the airways and lungs
* Chest x-ray
* ECG (heart tracing)
* Endoscopy -- camera down the throat to see burns in the esophagus (swallowing tube) and the stomach
* Fluids through the vein (by IV)
* Medicine to treat symptoms
* Surgical removal of burned skin (skin debridement)
* Tube through the mouth into the stomach to aspirate (suck out) the stomach, but only in cases of massive ingestion if the victim is seen within an hour of swallowing the poison and if there is no injury to the esophagus
* Washing of the skin (irrigation), perhaps every few hours for several days

**Outlook (Prognosis):**

How well the person does depends on the amount of poison swallowed and how quickly treatment is received. The faster the person gets medical help, the better the chance for recovery.

Swallowing diesel fuel can damage the linings of the:

* Esophagus
* Intestines
* Mouth
* Stomach
* Throat

Serious and permanent damage can occur if the diesel gets into the lungs.

Delayed injury may occur, including a hole forming in the throat, esophagus, stomach or lungs. This can lead to severe bleeding and infection, and may be fatal. Surgery may be needed to treat these complications.

The harsh taste of diesel fuel makes it unlikely that a large amount will be swallowed. However, cases of poisoning have occurred in people trying to suck (siphon) gas from an automobile tank using their mouth and a garden hose (or similar tube). This practice is very dangerous and is not advised.

---

**Diesel Oil**

Swallowing diesel fuel can damage the linings of the:

* **Esophagus**
* **Intestines**
* **Mouth**
* **Stomach**
* **Throat**

Serious and permanent damage can occur if the diesel gets into the lungs.

Delayed injury may occur, including a hole forming in the throat, esophagus, stomach or lungs. This can lead to severe bleeding and infection, and may be fatal. Surgery may be needed to treat these complications.

The harsh taste of diesel fuel makes it unlikely that a large amount will be swallowed. However, cases of poisoning have occurred in people trying to suck (siphon) gas from an automobile tank using their mouth and a garden hose (or similar tube). This practice is very dangerous and is not advised.

**How Well the Person Does**

How well the person does depends on the amount of poison swallowed and how quickly treatment is received. The faster the person gets medical help, the better the chance for recovery.

title: Diet - chronic kidney disease: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Diet for Chronic Kidney Disease**

When you have chronic kidney disease (CKD), your diet may need to change to keep the levels of electrolytes, minerals, and fluid in your body balanced. This is especially important if you're on dialysis.

**Function**

The purpose of this special diet is to limit the buildup of waste products in the body when you have CKD or are on dialysis. People on dialysis need to watch their fluid intake between treatments because most people on dialysis urinate very little, leading to a buildup of fluid in the body.

**Recommendations**

Ask your healthcare provider to refer you to a registered dietitian who specializes in kidney diets. Your dietitian can help create a personalized diet plan that meets your other health needs.

**CARBOHYDRATES**

If you don't have trouble eating carbohydrates, these foods are a good source of energy:

* Fruits
* Breads
* Grains
* Vegetables

You can replace calories from protein with:

* Hard candies
* Sugar
* Honey
* Jelly
* High-calorie desserts like pies, cakes, or cookies (limit those made with dairy, chocolate, nuts, or bananas)

**FATS**

Use monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats (like olive oil, canola oil, safflower oil) to protect your heart health. Talk to your provider or dietitian about fats and cholesterol that may increase your risk for heart problems.

**PROTEIN**

Low-protein diets may be helpful before starting dialysis. Your provider or dietitian may advise a lower-protein diet based on your weight, stage of disease, muscle mass, and other factors. However, you still need enough protein, so work with your provider to find the right balance for you.

Once you start dialysis, you'll need to eat more protein. A high-protein diet with fish, poultry, pork, or eggs at every meal may be recommended. People on dialysis should aim for 8-10 ounces (225-280 grams) of high-protein foods daily. Your provider or dietitian may suggest adding egg whites, egg white powder, or protein powder.

**CALCIUM AND PHOSPHOROUS**

Your healthcare provider will regularly check your calcium and phosphorous levels. Even in the early stages of CKD, phosphorous levels can get too high, leading to:

* Low blood calcium
* Itching

Limit dairy foods that contain large amounts of phosphorous, including milk, yogurt, and cheese. Some lower-phosphorous dairy options are:

* Tub margarine
* Butter
* Cream, ricotta, brie cheese
* Heavy cream
* Sherbet
* Nondairy whipped toppings

You may need to take calcium supplements to prevent bone disease and vitamin D to control the balance of calcium and phosphorous in your body. Your provider may also recommend medicines called "phosphorous binders" if diet changes alone don't work.

**FLUIDS**

In the early stages of kidney failure, you don't need to limit fluids. However, as your condition worsens or when you're on dialysis, you'll need to watch your fluid intake. In between dialysis sessions, too much fluid can build up in your body, leading to shortness of breath, a medical emergency.

Your provider and dialysis nurse will let you know how much fluid you should drink daily. Keep track of foods that contain a lot of water, such as soups, fruit-flavored gelatin, fruit-flavored ice pops, ice cream, grapes, melons, lettuce, tomatoes, and celery.

**SALT OR SODIUM**

Reducing sodium in your diet helps control high blood pressure, prevents thirst, and stops your body from holding onto extra fluid. Look for these words on food labels:

* Low-sodium
* No salt added
* Sodium-free
* Sodium-reduced
* Unsalted

Check all labels to see how much salt or sodium foods contain per serving. Avoid salty foods and don't use salt when cooking.

**POTASSIUM**

Too much potassium can build up in your body, leading to dangerous heart rhythms that can be fatal. Fruits and vegetables contain large amounts of potassium, so limit or avoid:

* Oranges and orange juice
* Nectarines
* Kiwis
* Raisins or other dried fruit
* Bananas
* Cantaloupe
* Honeydew
* Prunes
* Nectarines

Choose potassium-friendly fruits like peaches, grapes, pears, apples, berries, pineapple, plums, tangerines, and watermelon. When eating vegetables, choose:

* Broccoli
* Cabbage
* Carrots
* Cauliflower
* Celery
* Cucumber
* Eggplant
* Green and wax beans
* Lettuce
* Onion
* Peppers
* Watercress
* Zucchini
* Yellow squash

Limit or avoid asparagus, avocado, potatoes, tomatoes or tomato sauce, winter squash, pumpkin, and cooked spinach.

**IRON**

People with advanced kidney failure often have anemia and need extra iron. Many foods contain extra iron, such as:

* Liver
* Beef
* Pork
* Chicken
* Lima and kidney beans
* Iron-fortified cereals

Talk to your provider or dietitian about which foods with iron you can eat due to your kidney disease.

**References**

Goraya N, Wesson DE. Dietary approaches to kidney diseases. In: Yu ASL, Chertow GM, Luyckx VA, Marsden PA, Skorecki K, Taal MW, eds. Brenner and Rector's The Kidney. 11th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 60.

Levey AS, Sarnak MJ. Chronic kidney disease. In: Goldman L, Cooney KA, eds. Goldman-Cecil Medicine. 27th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2024:chap 116.

National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases website. Eating & nutrition for hemodialysis. www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/kidney-disease/kidney-failure/hemodialysis/eating-nutrition. Updated September 2016. Accessed September 8, 2023.

National Kidney Foundation website. Dietary guidelines for adults starting on hemodialysis. www.kidney.org/atoz/content/dietary_hemodialysis. Updated April 2019. Accessed September 8, 2023.

---

**Diet for Chronic Kidney Disease**

When you have chronic kidney disease (CKD), your diet may need to change to help keep the levels of electrolytes, minerals, and fluid in your body balanced. This is especially important if you're on dialysis.

**Function**

The purpose of this diet is to prevent the buildup of waste products in the body when you have CKD or are on dialysis.

**People on Dialysis**

If you're on dialysis, limiting fluid intake between treatments is crucial because most people on dialysis urinate very little. Without urination, fluid will build up in the body and cause too much fluid in the heart and lungs.

**Recommendations**

*   Ask your healthcare provider to refer you to a registered dietitian who specializes in kidney diets.
*   Your dietitian can help you create a diet that fits your other health needs and ensures you're taking in enough calories each day to keep you healthy and prevent the breakdown of body tissue.

**CARBOHYDRATES**

If you don't have a problem eating carbohydrates, these foods are a good source of energy. You may replace the calories from protein with:

*   Fruits
*   Breads
*   Grains
*   Vegetables
*   Hard candies
*   Sugar
*   Honey
*   Jelly

**FATS**

Fats can be a good source of calories. Use monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats (olive oil, canola oil, safflower oil) to protect your heart health.

**PROTEIN**

Low-protein diets may be helpful before you start dialysis. Your provider or dietitian may advise a lower-protein diet based on your weight, stage of disease, how much muscle you have, and other factors.

Once you start dialysis, you'll need to eat more protein. A high-protein diet with fish, poultry, pork, or eggs at every meal may be recommended.

People on dialysis should eat 8 to 10 ounces (225 to 280 grams) of high-protein foods each day. Your provider or dietitian may suggest adding egg whites, egg white powder, or protein powder.

**CALCIUM AND PHOSPHOROUS**

The minerals calcium and phosphorous will be checked often. Even in the early stages of CKD, phosphorous levels in the blood can get too high. This can cause:

*   Low blood calcium
*   Itching

You'll need to limit the amount of dairy foods you eat because they contain large amounts of phosphorous.

**FLUIDS**

In the early stages of kidney failure, you don't need to limit the fluid you drink. However, as your condition gets worse or when you're on dialysis, you'll need to watch the amount of liquid you take in.

Too much fluid can lead to shortness of breath, an emergency that needs immediate medical attention.

**SALT OR SODIUM**

Reducing sodium in your diet helps control high blood pressure and prevents your body from holding onto extra fluid. Look for these words on food labels:

*   Low-sodium
*   No salt added
*   Sodium-free
*   Sodium-reduced
*   Unsalted

Check all labels to see how much salt or sodium foods contain per serving.

**POTASSIUM**

Normal blood levels of potassium help keep your heart beating steadily. However, too much potassium can build up when the kidneys no longer function well. Dangerous heart rhythms may result, which can lead to death.

Fruits and vegetables contain large amounts of potassium, and for that reason should be limited to maintain a healthy heart.

**IRON**

People with advanced kidney failure also have anemia and usually need extra iron. Many foods contain extra iron (liver, beef, pork, chicken, lima and kidney beans, iron-fortified cereals). Talk to your provider or dietitian about which foods with iron you can eat because of your kidney disease.

**Tips**

*   Avoid salty foods
*   Freeze some juice in an ice cube tray and eat it like a fruit-flavored ice pop (you must count these ice cubes in your daily amount of fluids)
*   Stay cool on hot days

---

**Diet for Chronic Kidney Disease**

When you have chronic kidney disease (CKD), you may need to make changes to your diet. These changes can include limiting fluids, eating a low-protein diet, limiting salt, potassium, phosphorous, and other electrolytes, and getting enough calories if you are losing weight.

**Function of the Diet**

The purpose of this diet is to keep the levels of electrolytes, minerals, and fluid in your body balanced when you have CKD or are on dialysis. People on dialysis need this special diet to limit the buildup of waste products in the body. Limiting fluid intake between dialysis treatments is very important because most people on dialysis urinate very little.

**Recommendations**

*   Ask your health care provider to refer you to a registered dietitian to help you with your diet for kidney disease.
*   Take in enough calories each day to keep you healthy and prevent the breakdown of body tissue. Weigh yourself every morning to make sure you are meeting this goal.
*   Limit carbohydrates, protein, salt, potassium, phosphorous, and other electrolytes as recommended by your provider or dietitian.

**CARBOHYDRATES**

If you do not have a problem eating carbohydrates, these foods are a good source of energy. You can replace the calories from protein with:

*   Fruits
*   Breads
*   Grains
*   Vegetables
*   Hard candies
*   Sugar
*   Honey
*   Jelly

**FATS**

Fats can be a good source of calories. Make sure to use monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats (olive oil, canola oil, safflower oil) to protect your heart health.

**PROTEIN**

Low-protein diets may be helpful before you start dialysis. Your provider or dietitian may advise a lower-protein diet based on your weight, stage of disease, how much muscle you have, and other factors. But you still need enough protein, so work with your provider to find the right diet for you.

Once you start dialysis, you will need to eat more protein. A high-protein diet with fish, poultry, pork, or eggs at every meal may be recommended.

**CALCIUM AND PHOSPHOROUS**

The minerals calcium and phosphorous will be checked often. Even in the early stages of CKD, phosphorous levels in the blood can get too high. This can cause:

*   Low blood calcium
*   Itching

You will need to limit the amount of dairy foods you eat, because they contain large amounts of phosphorous. This includes milk, yogurt, and cheese.

**FLUIDS**

In the early stages of kidney failure, you do not need to limit the fluid you drink. But, as your condition gets worse, or when you are on dialysis, you will need to watch the amount of liquid you take in.

**SALT OR SODIUM**

Reducing sodium in your diet helps you control high blood pressure. It also keeps you from being thirsty, and prevents your body from holding onto extra fluid. Look for these words on food labels:

*   Low-sodium
*   No salt added
*   Sodium-free
*   Sodium-reduced
*   Unsalted

Check all labels to see how much salt or sodium foods contain per serving.

**POTASSIUM**

People with CKD also need to limit their potassium.

---

**Diet for Chronic Kidney Disease**

\n\n

As a person with chronic kidney disease (CKD), it's essential to follow a diet that helps manage your condition. Here are some guidelines to help you get started:

**Herbs vs Salt**

*   Herbs are safe and can be used as alternatives to salt.
*   Avoid using salt substitutes, which contain potassium.

**Potassium Limitations**

*   Fruits and vegetables contain large amounts of potassium, so limit or avoid:
    *   Oranges and orange juice
    *   Nectarines
    *   Kiwis
    *   Raisins or other dried fruit
    *   Bananas
    *   Cantaloupe
    *   Honeydew
    *   Prunes
    *   And nectarines
*   Choose potassium-rich foods like:
    *   Peaches
    *   Grapes
    *   Pears
    *   Apples
    *   Berries
    *   Pineapple
    *   Plums
    *   Tangerines
    *   Watermelon

**Vegetable Choices**

*   Limit or avoid:
    *   Asparagus
    *   Avocado
    *   Potatoes
    *   Tomatoes or tomato sauce
    *   Winter squash
    *   Pumpkin
    *   Cooked spinach
*   Choose potassium-rich vegetables like:
    *   Broccoli
    *   Cabbage
    *   Carrots
    *   Cauliflower
    *   Celery
    *   Cucumber
    *   Eggplant
    *   Green and wax beans
    *   Lettuce
    *   Onion
    *   Peppers
    *   Watercress
    *   Zucchini
    *   Yellow squash

**Iron Intake**

*   People with advanced kidney failure may need extra iron due to anemia.
*   Talk to your provider or dietitian about which foods with iron you can eat.

**Calories and Energy**

*   If you don't have a problem eating carbohydrates, these foods are a good source of energy.
*   Replace calories from protein with:
    *   Fruits
    *   Breads
    *   Grains
    *   Vegetables
    *   Hard candies
    *   Sugar
    *   Honey
    *   Jelly

**Fats and Cholesterol**

*   Use monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats (olive oil, canola oil, safflower oil) to protect your heart health.
*   Talk to your provider or dietitian about fats and cholesterol that may increase your risk for heart problems.

**Protein Intake**

*   Low-protein diets may be helpful before you start dialysis.
*   Your provider or dietitian may advise a lower-protein diet based on your weight, stage of disease, muscle mass, and other factors.
*   Once you start dialysis, you'll need to eat more protein. A high-protein diet with fish, poultry, pork, or eggs at every meal may be recommended.

**Calcium and Phosphorus**

*   The minerals calcium and phosphorous will be checked often.
*   Even in the early stages of CKD, phosphorous levels in the blood can get too high, causing:
    *   Low blood calcium
    *   Itching
*   Limit dairy foods that contain large amounts of phosphorous.
*   Some dairy foods are lower in phosphorous, including:
    *   Tub margarine
    *   Butter
    *   Cream
    *   Ricotta cheese
    *   Brie cheese
    *   Heavy cream
    *   Sherbet
    *   Nondairy whipped toppings

**Fluid Intake**

*   In the early stages of kidney failure, you don't need to limit fluid intake.
*   As your condition worsens or when on dialysis, watch the amount of liquid you take in.
*   Your provider and dialysis nurse will let you know how much you should drink every day.

**Tips for Managing Fluid Intake**

*   Use smaller cups or glasses
*   Turn over your cup after finishing it
*   Avoid salty foods
*   Freeze juice in an ice cube tray and eat it like a fruit-flavored ice pop (count these ice cubes in your daily amount of fluids)
*   Stay cool on hot days

---

**Diet for Chronic Kidney Disease**

As a person with chronic kidney disease (CKD), it's essential to follow a specific diet to manage your condition effectively. In this section, we'll discuss the foods you should avoid and include in your diet.

**Foods to Avoid**

* Asparagus
* Avocado
* Potatoes
* Tomatoes or tomato sauce
* Winter squash
* Pumpkin
* Cooked spinach

**IRON**

People with advanced kidney failure often have anemia, which means they need extra iron. Many foods contain iron, including:

* Liver
* Beef
* Pork
* Chicken
* Lima and kidney beans
* Iron-fortified cereals

Talk to your provider or dietitian about which foods with iron you can eat due to your kidney disease.

**CARBOHYDRATES**

If you don't have a problem eating carbohydrates, these foods are an excellent source of energy. If your provider has recommended a low-protein diet, you may replace the calories from protein with:

* Fruits
* Vegetables
* Whole grains

**FATS**

Fats can be a good source of calories. Make sure to use monounsaturated and polyunsaturated fats (olive oil, canola oil, safflower oil) to protect your heart health.

**PROTEIN**

Low-protein diets may be helpful before you start dialysis. Your provider or dietitian may advise a lower-protein diet based on your weight, stage of disease, muscle mass, and other factors. However, you still need enough protein, so work with your provider to find the right diet for you.

Once you start dialysis, you'll need to eat more protein. A high-protein diet with fish, poultry, pork, or eggs at every meal may be recommended.

People on dialysis should eat 8 to 10 ounces (225 to 280 grams) of high-protein foods each day. Your provider or dietitian may suggest adding egg whites, egg white powder, or protein powder.

**CALCIUM AND PHOSPHOROUS**

The minerals calcium and phosphorous will be checked often. Even in the early stages of CKD, phosphorous levels in the blood can get too high, causing:

* Bone disease
* Heart problems

You'll need to limit the amount of dairy foods you eat, as they contain large amounts of phosphorous. This includes milk, yogurt, and cheese. Some dairy foods are lower in phosphorous, such as:

* Cottage cheese
* Ricotta cheese

You may need to take calcium supplements to prevent bone disease and vitamin D to control the balance of calcium and phosphorous in your body.

**FLUIDS**

In the early stages of kidney failure, you don't need to limit the fluid you drink. However, as your condition worsens or when you're on dialysis, you'll need to watch the amount of liquid you take in.

Too much fluid can lead to shortness of breath, an emergency that needs immediate medical attention.

**SALT OR SODIUM**

Reducing sodium in your diet helps control high blood pressure and prevents your body from holding onto extra fluid. Look for these words on food labels:

* Less than 100 milligrams (mg) of salt per serving
* Low-sodium or no-salt-added

Check all labels to see how much salt or sodium foods contain per serving.

**POTASSIUM**

Normal blood levels of potassium help keep your heart beating steadily. However, too much potassium can build up when the kidneys no longer function well, causing:

* Dangerous heart rhythms
* Death

Fruits and vegetables contain large amounts of potassium, so limit them to maintain a healthy heart.

Choosing the right item from each food group can help control your potassium levels.

When eating fruits:

* Limit citrus fruits like oranges and grapefruits
* Choose apples, bananas, and berries instead

When eating vegetables:

* Limit potatoes and sweet potatoes
* Choose leafy greens like lettuce and spinach instead

---

**Diet for Chronic Kidney Disease**

\n\nWhen it comes to managing chronic kidney disease, a well-planned diet can make all the difference. In this section, we'll explore the importance of dietary changes in slowing down the progression of kidney disease.

**Eating and Nutrition for Hemodialysis**

For individuals starting hemodialysis, a special diet is crucial to ensure proper nutrition and prevent complications. The National Kidney Foundation recommends the following dietary guidelines:

*   **Low sodium intake**: Limiting sodium consumption can help reduce fluid buildup in the body.
*   **Fruits and vegetables**: Incorporating a variety of colorful fruits and vegetables into your diet can provide essential nutrients and antioxidants.

**Dietary Approaches to Kidney Diseases**

According to Goraya and Wesson, dietary approaches can play a significant role in managing kidney diseases. By making informed food choices, individuals with chronic kidney disease can help slow down the progression of their condition.

**Chronic Kidney Disease**

Learn more about chronic kidney disease, including its causes, symptoms, and treatment options.

**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics**

*   Chronic Kidney Disease

**Images**

*   Low sodium diet
*   Fruits and vegetables

title: Diet - liver disease: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Diet for Liver Disease**

Some people with liver disease must eat a special diet to help the liver function and protect it from working too hard.

**Function of Proteins**

Proteins normally help the body repair tissue, prevent fatty buildup, and damage to liver cells. In people with badly damaged livers, proteins are not properly processed, leading to waste products building up in the brain.

**Dietary Changes for Liver Disease**

Reducing animal protein intake can limit toxic waste product buildup.
Increasing carbohydrate intake to be proportional to protein consumption.
Eating fruits, vegetables, and lean protein sources like legumes, poultry, and fish. Avoid uncooked shellfish due to hepatitis A risk.
Taking vitamins and medicines prescribed by your healthcare provider for low blood count, nerve problems, or nutritional issues from liver disease.
Limiting salt intake to reduce fluid buildup and swelling in the liver.

**Side Effects of Liver Disease on Diet**

Liver disease can affect food absorption and protein production, influencing weight, appetite, and vitamin levels. Don't limit protein too much, as it may lead to amino acid deficiencies.

**Recommendations for Severe Liver Disease**

Eat large amounts of carbohydrate foods; carbohydrates should be the major source of calories.
Consume a moderate intake of fat, as prescribed by your provider, to prevent protein breakdown in the liver.
Have about 1.2 to 1.5 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight (84-105 grams for a 154-pound man).
Look for non-meat protein sources like beans, tofu, and dairy products when possible.
Take vitamin supplements, especially B-complex vitamins.
Many people with liver disease are deficient in vitamin D; ask your provider if you should take vitamin D supplements.
Limit sodium intake to 2000 milligrams per day or less to reduce fluid retention.

**Sample Menu**

Breakfast:

* 1 orange
* Cooked oatmeal with milk and sugar
* 1 slice of whole-wheat toast
* Strawberry jam
* Coffee or tea

Mid-morning snack:

* 4-8 ounces (240 milliliters) of milk or a piece of fruit

Lunch:

* 4 ounces (110 grams) of cooked lean fish, poultry, or meat
* A starch item (such as potatoes)
* A cooked vegetable
* Salad
* 2 slices of whole-grain bread
* 1 tablespoon (20 grams) of jelly
* Fresh fruit
* 8 ounces of milk

Mid-afternoon snack:

* 4-8 ounces of milk with graham crackers

Dinner:

* 4 ounces (110 grams) of cooked fish, poultry, or meat
* Starch item (such as potatoes)
* A cooked vegetable
* Salad
* 2 whole-grain rolls
* Fresh fruit or dessert
* 8 ounces of milk

Evening snack:

* 4-8 ounces of milk or a piece of fruit

---

**Diet for Liver Disease**

Some people with liver disease must eat a special diet. This diet helps the liver function and protects it from working too hard.

**Proteins and Their Role in the Body**

* Proteins help the body repair tissue.
* They prevent fatty buildup and damage to the liver cells.
* In people with badly damaged livers, proteins are not properly processed. Waste products may build up and affect the brain.

**Dietary Changes for Liver Disease**

* Reduce the amount of animal protein you eat. This will help limit the buildup of toxic waste products.
* Increase your intake of carbohydrates to be in proportion with the amount of protein you eat.
* Eat fruits and vegetables and lean protein such as legumes, poultry, and fish. Avoid uncooked shellfish due to the risk of hepatitis A.
* Take vitamins and medicines prescribed by your health care provider for low blood count, nerve problems, or nutritional problems from liver disease.
* Limit your salt intake. Salt in the diet may worsen fluid buildup and swelling in the liver.

**Side Effects of Liver Disease on Diet**

* Liver disease can affect the absorption of food and the production of proteins and vitamins.
* Your diet may influence your weight, appetite, and the amounts of vitamins in your body.
* DO NOT limit protein too much, because it can result in a lack of certain amino acids.

**Recommendations for People with Severe Liver Disease**

* Eat large amounts of carbohydrate foods. Carbohydrates should be the major source of calories in this diet.
* Eat a moderate intake of fat, as prescribed by the provider. The increased carbohydrates and fat help prevent protein breakdown in the liver.
* Have about 1.2 to 1.5 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight.
* Take vitamin supplements, especially B-complex vitamins.
* Many people with liver disease are deficient in vitamin D. Ask your provider if you should take vitamin D supplements.
* Limit the amount of sodium you eat to 2000 milligrams per day or less to reduce fluid retention.

**Sample Menu**

Breakfast:

1 orange
Cooked oatmeal with milk and sugar
1 slice of whole-wheat toast
Strawberry jam
Coffee or tea

Mid-morning snack:

4 to 8 ounces (240 milliliters) of milk or piece of fruit

Lunch:

4 ounces (110 grams) of cooked lean fish, poultry, or meat
A starch item (such as potatoes)
A cooked vegetable
Salad
2 slices of whole-grain bread
1 tablespoon (20 grams) of jelly
Fresh fruit
8 ounces of milk

Mid-afternoon snack:

4 to 8 ounces of milk with graham crackers

Dinner:

4 ounces (110 grams) of cooked fish, poultry, or meat
Starch item (such as potatoes)
A cooked vegetable
Salad
2 whole-grain rolls
Fresh fruit or dessert
8 ounces of milk

Evening snack:

4 to 8 ounces of milk or piece of fruit

---

**Diet for Liver Disease**

If you have liver disease, your diet should be well-balanced and easy to digest. The goal is to get the right amount of nutrition while avoiding foods that can make your condition worse.

**Sample Menu**

Here's a sample menu to help you plan your meals:

*   **Breakfast**
    *   2 slices of whole-grain bread
    *   1 tablespoon (20 grams) of jelly
    *   Fresh fruit
    *   8 ounces of milk
*   **Mid-morning snack**
    *   4 to 8 ounces of milk with graham crackers
*   **Lunch**
    *   4 ounces (110 grams) of cooked fish, poultry, or meat
    *   Starch item (such as potatoes)
    *   A cooked vegetable
    *   Salad
    *   2 whole-grain rolls
    *   Fresh fruit or dessert
    *   8 ounces of milk
*   **Mid-afternoon snack**
    *   4 to 8 ounces of milk or piece of fruit
*   **Dinner**
    *   4 ounces (110 grams) of cooked fish, poultry, or meat
    *   Starch item (such as potatoes)
    *   A cooked vegetable
    *   Salad
    *   2 whole-grain rolls
    *   Fresh fruit or dessert
    *   8 ounces of milk
*   **Evening snack**
    *   4 to 8 ounces of milk or piece of fruit

**General Recommendations**

Most of the time, you don't have to avoid specific foods. However, if your liver disease is severe, your provider may recommend certain dietary changes. These changes will depend on how well your liver is working.

**Consult Your Provider**

Talk to your provider if you have questions about your diet or symptoms. They can help you determine the best course of action for your specific situation.

title: Diet after gastric banding : MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Diet After Gastric Banding**

After having laparoscopic gastric banding surgery, you'll need to adjust your diet to ensure a smooth recovery.

**When You Go Home From the Hospital**

For 2 to 3 weeks after surgery, you'll only eat liquid or pureed food. Gradually introduce soft foods, followed by regular foods.

**A New Way of Eating**

*   Eat slowly and chew each bite thoroughly.
*   Take 20-30 minutes to finish a meal.
*   Stop eating when satisfied, not full.
*   Use small plates and utensils to control portion sizes.

**Foods to Avoid or Approach with Caution**

*   Pasta, rice, bread, raw vegetables, and meats (especially steak) may cause discomfort if not chewed properly. Consider staying away from these foods or adding low-fat sauces for easier digestion.
*   Dry foods like popcorn and nuts, as well as fibrous foods like celery and corn, can be problematic.

**Hydration**

Drink up to 8 cups (64 ounces) of water or other calorie-free liquids daily:

*   Avoid drinking during meals to prevent filling up too quickly.
*   Take small sips when drinking.
*   Ask your provider about using a straw, as it may introduce air into your stomach.

**Nutritional Considerations**

Ensure you're getting enough protein, vitamins, and minerals while losing weight. Focus on:

*   Protein-rich foods like skinless chicken, lean beef or pork, fish, whole eggs or egg whites, beans, and dairy products.
*   Combining foods with texture together with protein can help stay satisfied longer.

**Supplements**

Your provider may prescribe supplements to address potential vitamin and mineral deficiencies:

*   Multivitamin with iron
*   Vitamin B12
*   Calcium (1,200 mg per day) and vitamin D

**Regular Checkups**

Schedule regular visits with your healthcare provider to monitor your weight, discuss any diet-related issues, and ensure you're eating well.

**Calories Still Count**

Read food labels to avoid high-calorie foods. Be mindful of:

*   Foods containing a lot of fats, sugar, or carbohydrates.
*   "Slider" foods that dissolve easily or pass quickly through the band.
*   Limiting alcohol consumption, as it's high in calories but low in nutrition.

**When to Call the Doctor**

Contact your provider if you experience:

*   Weight gain or slowed weight loss
*   Vomiting after eating
*   Persistent tiredness
*   Dizziness or excessive sweating

---

**Diet after Gastric Banding**

After gastric banding surgery, it's essential to follow specific diet guidelines to ensure a smooth recovery and effective weight loss.

**When You Go Home From the Hospital**

*   Eat only liquid or pureed food for 2 to 3 weeks after surgery.
*   Gradually introduce soft foods, followed by regular foods.
*   Be mindful of your new stomach pouch's limited capacity, which may hold only a tablespoonful of food at first.

**A New Way of Eating**

*   Eat slowly and chew each bite thoroughly to avoid discomfort or pain.
*   Take 20-30 minutes to eat a meal, and stop when you feel satisfied rather than full.
*   Eat 6 small meals throughout the day instead of 3 larger ones.
*   Avoid snacking between meals and use small plates and utensils to control portion sizes.

**Nutritional Considerations**

*   Ensure you're getting enough protein, vitamins, and minerals through a balanced diet that includes:
    *   Protein sources like skinless chicken, lean beef or pork, fish, whole eggs or egg whites, beans, and dairy products.
    *   Fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
*   Your healthcare provider may prescribe supplements to address potential deficiencies.

**Calories Still Count**

*   Read food labels to avoid high-calorie foods and drinks.
*   Limit your intake of fats, sugar, and carbohydrates, particularly "slider" foods that dissolve easily or pass quickly through the band.
*   Avoid carbonated drinks and sugary beverages.

By following these diet guidelines, you'll be better equipped to manage your weight loss journey and maintain a healthy lifestyle after gastric banding surgery.

---

**Diet after Gastric Banding**

After gastric banding surgery, you will need to adjust your diet to ensure proper nutrition and prevent complications.

**Eating Habits**

* Eat slowly and chew each bite very slowly and completely.
* Take 20 to 30 minutes to eat a meal.
* If you vomit or have pain under your breastbone during or after eating, you may be eating too fast.
* Eat 6 small meals during the day instead of 3 bigger meals.
* Do not snack between meals.
* Stop eating when you feel satisfied. Try not to eat until you feel full.

**Food Choices**

* Some foods may cause discomfort if not chewed completely, such as:
	+ Pasta
	+ Rice
	+ Bread
	+ Raw vegetables
	+ Meats (especially steak)
* Consider staying away from these types of foods and consult with your provider.
* Adding a low-fat sauce can make them easier to digest.

**Hydration**

* Drink up to 8 cups (64 ounces), or 2 liters, of water or other calorie-free liquids every day.
* Do not drink anything for 30 minutes after a meal.
* Take small sips when drinking. Do not gulp.
* Ask your provider before using a straw, as it may bring air into your stomach.

**Nutritional Requirements**

* Ensure you are getting enough protein, vitamins, and minerals while losing weight.
* Eat mostly protein, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains to support your body's needs.
* Low-fat protein choices include:
	+ Skinless chicken
	+ Lean beef or pork
	+ Fish
	+ Whole eggs or egg whites
	+ Beans
	+ Dairy products (low-fat or nonfat hard cheeses, cottage cheese, milk, yogurt)

**Supplements**

* Your provider may prescribe supplements to ensure you are getting enough essential vitamins and minerals, including:
	+ Multivitamin with iron
	+ Vitamin B12
	+ Calcium (1,200 mg per day) and vitamin D

---

**Diet after Gastric Banding**

After gastric banding surgery, you will need to follow a special diet to ensure your weight loss is successful and to prevent any complications.

**Supplements**

You may need to take supplements to get enough of certain vitamins and minerals. These include:

*   Multivitamin with iron
*   Vitamin B12
*   Calcium (1,200 mg per day) and vitamin D

Your body can only absorb about 500 mg of calcium at a time, so divide your daily dose into 2 or 3 portions.

**Regular Checkups**

You will need to have regular checkups with your provider to monitor your weight loss and ensure you are eating well. These visits are a good opportunity to discuss any problems you are experiencing with your diet or other issues related to your surgery and recovery.

**Eating for Weight Loss**

To lose weight successfully, you need to make sure you are getting enough protein, vitamins, and minerals. Eating mostly protein, fruits, vegetables, and whole grains will help your body get the nutrients it needs.

Protein is particularly important because your body needs it to build muscles and other tissues. Low-fat protein choices include:

*   Skinless chicken
*   Lean beef or pork
*   Fish
*   Whole eggs or egg whites
*   Beans
*   Dairy products, such as low-fat or nonfat hard cheeses, cottage cheese, milk, and yogurt

Combining foods with texture together with protein can help you feel fuller for longer. Examples include a salad with grilled chicken or toast with low-fat cottage cheese.

**Avoiding High-Calorie Foods**

To avoid gaining weight or slowing down your weight loss, read food labels to avoid high-calorie foods. Also, steer clear of:

*   Foods that contain a lot of fats, sugar, or carbohydrates
*   "Slider" foods that dissolve easily or pass quickly through the band
*   Drinks with sugar, fructose, or corn syrup
*   Carbonated drinks like soda and sparkling water

Let soda go flat before drinking it.

**When to Call Your Provider**

If you experience any of the following, contact your provider:

*   You are gaining weight or stopping weight loss
*   You are vomiting after eating
*   You feel tired all the time
*   You have dizziness or are sweating

By following these dietary guidelines and staying in touch with your provider, you can ensure a successful weight loss journey after gastric banding surgery.

---

**Diet after Gastric Banding**

\n\n

**Post-Surgical Diet Guidelines**

After undergoing gastric banding, it's essential to follow a specific diet to ensure proper healing and minimize complications. The following guidelines are based on recommendations from reputable medical sources:

*   **Initial Post-Surgery Period**: During the first week or two after surgery, patients should focus on clear liquids, such as water, clear broth, and electrolyte-rich beverages like sports drinks. This helps prevent dehydration and promotes healing.
*   **Soft Foods**: Once cleared by their doctor, patients can gradually introduce soft foods into their diet. These may include mashed potatoes, cooked pasta, scrambled eggs, and other easy-to-digest options.
*   **Solid Foods**: As the banding adjusts and the stomach adapts, solid foods can be reintroduced in small portions. It's crucial to chew food thoroughly and eat slowly to avoid discomfort or pain.

**Nutritional Considerations**

In addition to following a specific diet, patients should also pay attention to their overall nutritional intake:

*   **Protein-Rich Foods**: Incorporating protein-rich foods like lean meats, fish, and legumes can help maintain muscle mass and support overall health.
*   **Fiber-Rich Foods**: A balanced diet that includes fiber-rich foods like fruits, vegetables, and whole grains can promote digestive health and prevent constipation.
*   **Vitamin and Mineral Supplements**: Patients may require vitamin and mineral supplements to ensure they're getting all the necessary nutrients. Consult with a healthcare provider or registered dietitian for personalized recommendations.

**Long-Term Dietary Adjustments**

After gastric banding, patients will need to make long-term dietary adjustments to maintain their weight loss and overall health:

*   **Portion Control**: Eating smaller, more frequent meals can help manage hunger and prevent overeating.
*   **Balanced Diet**: Focus on consuming a balanced diet that includes a variety of whole foods, lean proteins, and healthy fats.
*   **Regular Follow-Ups**: Schedule regular follow-up appointments with your healthcare provider to monitor progress, address concerns, and make any necessary adjustments to your diet.

By following these guidelines and consulting with a healthcare provider or registered dietitian, patients can ensure a smooth recovery and maintain optimal health after gastric banding.

title: Diet and cancer: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Diet and Cancer**

You can reduce your overall risk of developing many types of cancer by following a healthy diet that includes plenty of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.

**DIET AND BREAST CANCER**

The link between nutrition and breast cancer has been well studied. To reduce risk of breast cancer the American Cancer Society (ACS) recommends:

*   Get regular physical activity of moderate intensity for at least 30 minutes a day 5 times a week.
*   Maintain a healthy weight throughout life.
*   Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Consume at least 2½ cups (300 grams) of fruits and vegetables daily.
*   Limit alcoholic beverages to no more than 2 drinks/day for men; 1 drink/day for women.

Other things to consider:

*   Data on the role of high soy intake (in the form of supplements) is inconclusive regarding hormone-sensitive cancers in women. Consuming a diet that contains moderate amounts of soy foods before adulthood may be beneficial.
*   Breastfeeding may reduce a mother's risk of developing breast or ovarian cancer.

**DIET AND PROSTATE CANCER**

The ACS recommends the following lifestyle choices to reduce prostate cancer risk:

*   Get regular physical activity of moderate intensity for at least 30 minutes a day five times a week.
*   Maintain a healthy weight throughout life.
*   Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Consume at least 2½ cups (300 grams) of fruits and vegetables daily.
*   Limit alcoholic beverages to no more than 2 drinks/day for men.

Other things to consider:

*   Your health care provider may suggest that men limit their use of calcium supplements and not exceed the recommended amount of calcium from foods and beverages.

**DIET AND COLON OR RECTAL CANCER**

The ACS recommends the following to reduce colorectal cancer risk:

*   Limit intake of red and processed meat. Avoid charbroiling meat.
*   Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Consume at least 2½ cups (300 grams) of fruits and vegetables daily. Broccoli may be particularly beneficial.
*   Avoid excess alcohol consumption.
*   Eat recommended amounts of calcium and get enough vitamin D.
*   Eat more omega-3 fatty acids (fatty fish, flaxseed oil, walnuts) than omega-6 fatty acids (corn oil, safflower oil, and sunflower oil).
*   Maintain a healthy weight throughout life. Avoid obesity and buildup of belly fat.

**DIET AND STOMACH OR ESOPHAGEAL CANCER**

The ACS recommends the following lifestyle choices to reduce stomach and esophageal cancer risk:

*   Eat a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Consume at least 2½ cups (300 grams) of fruits and vegetables daily.
*   Lower your intake of processed meats, smoked, nitrite-cured, and salt-preserved foods; emphasize plant-based proteins.
*   Get regular physical activity of at least 30 minutes a day 5 times a week.
*   Maintain a healthy body weight throughout life.

**RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CANCER PREVENTION**

The American Institute for Cancer Research's 10 recommendations for cancer prevention include:

*   Be as lean as possible without becoming underweight.
*   Be physically active for at least 30 minutes every day.
*   Avoid sugary drinks. Limit consumption of calorie-dense foods. (Artificial sweeteners in moderate amounts have not been shown to cause cancer.)
*   Eat more of a variety of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and legumes such as beans.
*   Limit consumption of red meats (such as beef, pork and lamb) and avoid processed meats.
*   If consumed at all, limit alcoholic drinks to 2 per day for men and 1 per day for women.
*   Limit consumption of salty foods and foods processed with salt (sodium).
*   DO NOT use supplements to protect against cancer.
*   It is best for mothers to breastfeed exclusively for up to 6 months and then add other liquids and foods.
*   After treatment, cancer survivors should follow the recommendations for cancer prevention.

**RESOURCES**

Dietary Guidelines for Americans -- www.myplate.gov
The American Cancer Society is an excellent source of information on cancer prevention -- www.cancer.gov/
The American Institute for Cancer Research -- www.aicr.org/cancer-prevention/healthy-eating/new-american-plate/
The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics provides sound dietary advice on a wide range of topics -- www.eatright.org/
The National Cancer Institute is a government gateway to the accurate information on cancer prevention --www.cancer.gov/

**Alternative Names**

Fiber and cancer; Cancer and fiber; Nitrates and cancer; Cancer and nitrates

**References**

Basen-Engquist K, Brown P, Coletta AM, Savage M, Maresso KC, Hawk E. Lifestyle and cancer prevention. In: Niederhuber JE, Armitage JO, Kastan MB, Doroshow JH, Tepper JE, eds. Abeloff's Clinical Oncology. 6th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2020:chap 22.

Kumar V, Abbas AK, Aster JC. Environmental and nutritional diseases. In: Kumar V, Abbas AK, Aster JC, eds. Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease. 10th ed. Philadelphia, PA: Elsevier; 2021:chap 9.

National Institutes of Health, National Cancer Institute website. SEER training modules, cancer risk factors. training.seer.cancer.gov/disease/cancer/risk.html. Accessed April 20, 2023.

Rock CL, Thomson C, Gansler T, et al. American Cancer Society guideline for diet and physical activity for cancer prevention. CA Cancer J Clin. 2020;70(4):245-271. PMID: 32515498 pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32515498/.

Snetselaar LG, de Jesus JM, DeSilva DM, Stoody EE. Dietary guidelines for Americans, 2020-2025: understanding the scientific process, guidelines, and key recommendations. Nutr Today. 2021;56(6):287-295. PMID: 34987271 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8713704/.

**Review Date**

4/13/2023

**Updated by**

Stefania Manetti, RD/N, CDCES, RYT200, My Vita Sana LLC - Nourish and heal through food, San Jose, CA. Review provided by VeriMed Healthcare Network. Also reviewed by David C. Dugdale, MD, Medical Director, Brenda Conaway, Editorial Director, and the A.D.A.M. Editorial team.

**Learn how to cite this page**

Related MedlinePlus Health Topics
Cancer
Images
Phytochemicals
Diet and cancer

---

*   Eat more of a variety of vegetables, fruits, whole grains, and legumes such as beans.
*   Limit consumption of red meats (such as beef, pork and lamb) and avoid processed meats.
*   If consumed at all, limit alcoholic drinks to 2 per day for men and 1 per day for women.
*   Limit consumption of salty foods and foods processed with salt (sodium).
*   DO NOT use supplements to protect against cancer.
*   It is best for mothers to breastfeed exclusively for up to 6 months and then add other liquids and foods.
